security_audit.summary: This skill uses Playwright for browser automation and includes a server management script that executes subprocess commands. The capabilities align with its stated purpose of web application testing. No evidence of credential theft, data exfiltration, or malicious network behavior. The shell=True subprocess pattern is standard for server management workflows.

medium_findings.title: Subprocess execution with shell=True
medium_findings.description:
The with_server.py script uses subprocess.Popen with shell=True to execute server commands and user-provided commands. While this is necessary for the script's purpose (managing server lifecycle), shell=True can be a security concern if untrusted input is passed. The script accepts arbitrary commands via --server and command-line arguments, which are then executed on the user's system.

Relevant code at scripts/with_server.py:69-74:
```python
process = subprocess.Popen(
    server['cmd'],
    shell=True,
    stdout=subprocess.PIPE,
    stderr=subprocess.PIPE
)
```

And at line 88:
```python
result = subprocess.run(args.command)
```

An attacker who could influence the server commands or the command to run could potentially execute arbitrary code. Users should only run this script with trusted commands.

content.value_statement: Testing web applications manually is time-consuming and error-prone. This skill provides Playwright automation tools to verify frontend functionality, capture screenshots, and debug browser behavior automatically.
actual_capabilities: Run Playwright automation scripts for web app testing
Start and manage local development servers automatically
Capture browser screenshots of rendered pages
Discover and inspect page elements (buttons, links, inputs)
Capture and analyze console logs during browser sessions
limitations: Only supports local web applications and file:// URLs
Requires Playwright and browser binaries installed
Cannot test remote or production websites without modification
Scripts must be written in Python using the Playwright API

use_cases.title: Test React, Vue, or Svelte apps
use_cases.description: Verify component interactions and catch regressions in local development builds

use_cases.title: Automate UI test scripts
use_cases.description: Create repeatable test scripts that click through forms and validate page states

use_cases.title: Debug frontend-backend integration
use_cases.description: Start both backend and frontend servers, then run automated tests against the full stack

prompt_templates.title: Static HTML test
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a Playwright script to open path/to/local/file.html, take a screenshot, and verify the page title contains 'Example'

prompt_templates.title: Form automation
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a Playwright script that navigates to localhost:3000, fills in username and password fields, clicks the login button, and captures the console output

prompt_templates.title: Element discovery
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a script to discover all buttons, links, and input fields on http://localhost:5173, save a screenshot, and output the element count for each type

prompt_templates.title: Multi-server test
prompt_templates.prompt: Use with_server.py to start a backend on port 3000 and frontend on port 5173, then run a Playwright test that makes API calls and verifies the UI responds correctly

output_examples.input: Write a Playwright script to test a login form
output: Opening browser and navigating to login page
Found 3 input fields: username (text), password (password), remember_me (checkbox)
Found 2 buttons: Sign In, Forgot Password
Page loaded successfully - URL changed to /dashboard

best_practices: Always wait for network idle state before inspecting dynamic web apps
Use descriptive selectors like text= or role= instead of fragile CSS paths
Close browser properly with browser.close() to avoid resource leaks
anti_patterns: Do not inspect DOM before waiting for networkidle on single-page applications
Avoid hardcoding sleep delays; use explicit waits instead
Do not use nth-child selectors that break when elements are added or removed

faq.question: Which browsers are supported?
faq.answer: Playwright supports Chromium, Firefox, and WebKit. The scripts use headless Chromium by default for fastest execution.

faq.question: Can I test remote websites?
faq.answer: Yes, change localhost URLs to any website URL. Note that some sites may block headless browser automation.

faq.question: How do I handle authentication in tests?
faq.answer: Use page.fill() to enter credentials, or set browser storage cookies using page.context.storage_state() to reuse sessions.

faq.question: Is my test data safe?
faq.answer: All testing runs locally. No data is sent to external servers. Screenshots and logs are saved to local directories you specify.

faq.question: Why are my tests failing on dynamic apps?
faq.answer: Most failures occur because scripts inspect DOM before JavaScript completes. Always use page.wait_for_load_state('networkidle') first.

faq.question: How is this different from Selenium?
faq.answer: Playwright is faster, more reliable, has better async support, and automatically waits for elements. It requires no external drivers.
